cab.content:
(THIS DOCUMENT IS THE PROPERTY OF HIS BRITANNIC MAJESTY'S GOVERNMENT).
SECRET. Copy No. 3
C.P.-2105.
CABINET.
EVACUATION OF REFUGEES FROM THE CRIMEA.
The accompanying paraphrases of telegrams to and from the Commander-in-Chief, Mediterranean, have been received from the Admiralty, and are circulated to the Cabinet for Information.
(Signed) M.P.A.HANKEY.
Secretary, Cabinet.
2 Whitehall Gardens, S.W.
17th November, 1920. I.
From Commander-in-Chief, Mediterranean Afloat to Admirality, dated 15th November, 1920.
No. 588Z.
Situation report. All British subjects who wished to leave the Crimea have now been withdrawn and all H.M.ships have left the Crimea. About 12,000 refugees have arrived in French and Russian steamers which are at anchor off Moda opposite Seraglie Point, where all ships from the Crimea have been ordered to assemble by the French. About 28,000 more refugees are expected. Half this total of 40,000 refugees are ?soldiers. All effective Russian Warships including submarines, are believed to be on their way to Constantinople with Russian flag aft and French flag at the Main. General Wrangel and his staff are coming on board Cruiser "Korniloff". A French Commission is handling the whole question.
1403/15.
II.
From Admiralty to Commander-in-Chief, Mediterranean afloat, dated 15th November, 1920. Sent: 1139.
421Z. PRIORITY.
Requested that you report what transports, if any, are being retained for the evacuation of British refugees from the Crimea.
III.
From Commander-in-Chief, Mediterranean Afloat, to Admiralty, dated 16th November, 1920.
Received 5.45 a.m.
589Z.
In reply to your 421Z. None.
1803/15.
